Bakgrund till detta projekt är att vi lever i en allt mer globaliserad värld där kunskaper om andra kulturer, språk och social kompetens är en nödvändighet.  Därför vill vi ge våra elever möjlighet till praktik i andra länder. En fördjupad förståelse kräver mer personliga möten mellan ungdomar från olika länder, vilket kan ske i skolsammanhang eller i arbetslivet. I dessa möten växer förståelse för att människor utifrån olika erfarenheter, olika sätt att värdera och tänka bygger samhällen olika. Vi har valt England och Lettland därför att vi har goda kontakter sedan många år tillbaka med stora hotell och butiker samt ett barnhem i Lettland. Eleverna möter en vardag som de inte har erfarenhet av i Sverige. 



Syftet är att vi vill uppmuntra och göra det möjligt för elever som p.g.a. ekonomiska eller av sociala skäl inte har möjlighet att få denna erfarenhet som det innebär att åka utomlands och möta andra kulturer, samhällsskikt och andra sociala kontexter. Ytterligare ett syfte är att vi vill att eleverna ska lära sig möta människor i andra kulturer, lära sig deras seder och bruk samt tillgodogöra sig engelskan på ett djupare, bredare och mer professionell nivå, helst bli ”native speaker”.

I examensmålen för Handel- och administrations programmet betonas att eleverna ska utveckla förmåga att hantera det personliga mötet i olika sammanhang. Attityder, värderingar och förhållningssätt påverkar försäljnings- och servicesituationer därför vill vi ge våra elever möjligheter ökad kunskap för ovannämnda område. Service och kommunikation innebär kontakt mellan människor och länder.



Barn och fritidsprogrammets examensmål betonar möte mellan människor och eleverna skall ges möjlighet att reflektera över och diskutera sociala och kulturella frågor.



I Restaurang- och livsmedelsprogrammet examensmål finns en stark internationell prägel därför ska kunskaper om livsmedel och måltider i andra kulturer ingå i utbildningen eftersom branschen är en del av en internationell arbetsmarknad.



Deltagare

Vår önskan är att ca 40 elever från årskurs 2 och 3 från Holavedsgymnasiet ska kunna deltaga i detta projekt under en två-års period. De elever som kommer i fråga till detta projekt ska ha visat hög social kompetens och social mognad. Våra mottagarorganisationer i England och Lettland är, Randolph Macdonald hotels, Malmaison hotels, Primark, Marks & Spencer och Childrens village of Grasi där vi har vi goda och professionella kontakter sedan många år tillbaka. 



Genomförande 

Eleverna kommer att praktisera i tre-fem veckor per period p.g.a. att skolan har sina praktikperioder utlagda i intervall som infaller under V.45-49 i åk3, V.8-12 i åk 3, samt V.17-21 i åk 2 med början under hösten 2014. Tre veckors praktik för BF-eleverna på barnhemmet p.g. a. avnämarens rekommendationer med anledning av elevernas unga ålder och den psykiskt tunga verklighet eleverna möter i Lettland under sin APL-period.



Beskrivning av APL/aktiviteter

Englands kultur har påverkat så många andra i hela världen. Engelskan är ju också det viktigaste språket att behärska idag.

Att möta engelsk och internationell mat-, service- och handelskultur och få inblick i den samt hur man bedriver service i ett internationellt perspektiv är mycket värdefullt för våra RL- och HA-elever. 



På barnhemmet ska eleverna träna sitt pedagogiska ledarskap genom att planera, genomföra och utvärdera pedagogiska aktiviteter. Eleverna ska också reflektera och jämföra levnads- och uppväxtvillkor enligt Maslows och Bronfenbrenners teorier. Ett annat kunskapskrav är att eleverna skall observera pedagogiska förhållningssätt och metoder utifrån deras erfarenheter och kunskaper från Sverige.



Förväntat resultat och önskvärda effekter

Ett högt prioriterat resultat för samtliga deltagande program är att eleverna ska få fördjupad kunskap i engelska språket, internationella och globala erfarenheter. Elever från andra ekonomiska och sociala bakgrunder ska få möjlighet att ta del av internationella och mångkulturella miljöer. Vår önskan är att eleverna ska få en högre anställningsbarhet och en tydlig yrkesidentitet enligt examensmålen för programmen. Efter avslutad gymnasieutbildning och med denna erfarenhet  av arbete  utomlands är vår förhoppning att eleverna skall öka sin mobilitet inom EU  och söka sig utomlands för arbete.



Långsiktighet

Vårt projekt ska även fungera som ett pilotprojekt på vårt gymnasium, så att alla elever på våra yrkesprogram i framtiden ska kunna erbjudas denna möjlighet. En intressant och givande utbildning på gymnasienivå är avgörande för en relativt liten kommun som Tranås (drygt 18000 invånare). Det här bidrar till att göra Holavedsgymnasiet bättre och därmed mer attraktivt för elever att söka. 

Vår önskan är att våra elever ska utveckla ett entreprenöriellt förhållningssätt, våga utmana sig själv i sin personliga utveckling, få motivation till högre studier och på så sätt får vi eleverna på Holavedsgymnasiet att ta ansvar för sitt eget livslånga lärande.

The background of this project is the fact that we live in a more globalised world in which knowledge about other cultures, languages and social skills are indispensable. Therefore, we want to offer our students the opportunity to do vocational training 
abroad. We have chosen England and Latvia because we have close contacts since many years back with well-renowned hotels and stores, additionally an orphanage in Latvia. Our purpose is to encourage and enable students to gain the experience it implies to meet other cultures, social strata and other social contexts which they otherwise do not have the chance to acquire. Moreover, we want our students to learn how to meet people from other cultures, learn their traditions, and acquire English skills on a deeper, wider and more professional level.

Our wish is that approximately 29 students from year 2 and 3 from The Business and Administration programme, The Restaurant and Food Management programme and The Child Recreation programme at Holavedsgymnasiet will be able to participate in this project during a period of two years. The students in question must have proved great social skills and social maturity. Our partner organisations in England and Latvia are Malmaison hotels, Primark, Marks & Spencer, and Childrens village of Grasi. It is enormously valuable for our students at The Business and Administration programme and The Restaurant and Food Management programme to come in contact with English and international food-, service-, and business culture and obtain an insight in it; additionally learn how to provide service in an international perspective. At the orphanage, the students should mainly practice their pedagogical leadership by planning, effecting and evaluating pedagogical activities. 

A primary result for all participating programmes is that the students improve their English skills and acquire international and global experience. The longer term benefit of this project is to offer more students this opportunity in the future, which leads to our school, Holavedsgymnasiet, being more attractive to apply to. In conclusion, we want our students to develop an entrepreneurial approach, increase the employability, have the courage to challenge themselves, and acquire a better comprehension of other cultures. In this way, we make the students at Holavedsgymnasiet take responsibility for their own lifelong learning.
YW - Global Week: Youth in Action for Global Advocacy and Poverty Eradication

Global Week is an international mobility of youth workers under the theme "Youth in Action for Global Advocacy and Poverty Eradication". Global Week has been a flagship project of Y Global designed to engage young people on global injustices under the "Stop Poverty campaign". The project takes 50 participants (young people selected based on their involvement and affinity to the themes at hand) through advocacy work at local, regional and global level issues with a focus on policy reforms. The project is designed in line with the European youth strategy.

The objectives of Global Week are:

1. To equip participants with leadership skills and youth work techniques for social intervention in local communities. 

2. To increase knowledge, active citizenship and engagement on pressuring issues (such as employment, health, migration, human rights and environment) affecting young people at community, national, European and global levels.

3.To promote the active citizenship, social inclusion and solidarity of all young people.

4. To equip young leaders networks/relationships across cultural and religious boundaries as part of a youth empowerment process in increasing multicultural societies and promote European values such as diversity and tolerance.

5. To strengthen a European network of young leaders who can share best practices and experiences.

6. To give participants and, through them, society a better understanding of advocacy work and why it is so important for the reduction of poverty at the european and global levels.

The activities will provide participants with tools to better themselves in the filed of advocacy and contribute to poverty reduction, using a variety of tools of non-formal education, including Subject to Citizen and Human Library.

The participants will develop their abilities in advocacy and will become more aware of how it can be used to diminish resolve a wide spectrum of problems, including poverty, youth exclusion and radicalization.
They will take all these new skills back to their communities where they will use them, and teach others how to use them, in order to solve at least some of the problems that are present there. In the long run, it is expected that networks will be formed, which will spread their activities accross regions and countries.

Learning to Stand Up y is a seminar organised by YMCA Germany for NGOs across Europe to mainstream skills regarding work with diversity and vulnerability, youth workers resilience and advocacy into our organisations. To do so, we aim to address young leaders (under 30s), from around 28 countries in Europe. We aim at increasing awareness among our participants about diversity and vulnerability, to increase knowledge about resilience mechanism for youth workers working with these themes, and to empower them to take an active role in ttheir communities advocating for the diverse and vulnerable young people they work with. We also aim at turning the role of our NGOs towards more socially relevant activities, more inclusive of vulnerable groups and attentive to their needs and the needs of their communities. We also hope that thy will take a more active role in advocating for social justice at a local, national and European level.

Peacemaker Global Week is 2018's iteration of Global Week, a training that has been organised and implemented by KFUK-KFUM Global since 1988. Through this event Y Global aims to further empower young youth workers in the field of advocacy in general, and in issues relating to movement building, wealth inequality, human rights, peacemaking and environmental awarness in particular, in compliance with our main thematic areas.

As part of the world YMCA and World YWCA, Y Global aims to strengthen the relationships we have with our partners from the movements, organisations that are of similar ideology and with which we have common goals. Extremism is a serious issues for many young people in many countries and we believe training in non-violent advocacy can be an important tool for youth workers to mobilise young people to stand up against extremism.

50 young youth workers from Norway, Romania, Sweden, Finland, The United Kingdon, France, Czech Republic, Spain, Macedonia, Denmark and Portugal will take part in activities both at their venue in Nærsnes, Royken municipality where they will have seminars, workshops and teambuilding activities; and in Oslo where they will organise and carry out a mobilisation event.

Through this mobility Y Global wants to make sure that the youth workers attending will be able to reach their full potential. They may have the motivation, but they may not have the knowledge and tools to follow through on their goals. This training is aimed at resolving that.
The overarching issues that we will address is youth involvement and youth power, and the main need that we will try to satisfy is the need of youth workers to manage to mobilise youth effectively. Peacemaker is a tool and an informal movement within the YMCA and YWCA networks aiming to give more power to young people. We believe that young people have the capacity to be active citizens implementing policy empowerment of other young people with the aim of engaging in policy advocacy. Hence, by addressing policy gaps in areas where young people experience injustice in our society, we are able to mobilise youth workers and young people in a non-violent change process aimed at creating justice for young people. We believe that this is the best way to reduce extremism and build peace in our communities.
Advocacy is the main tool used and leadership training in advocacy and related advocacy issues are the main focuses of Peacemaker Global Week.

50 youth workers from grassroots youth organisations in Europe part in a highly interactive and innovative event in order to develop new leadership skills and increase capacity in service deliver for young people in their communities. This projects is part of a larger initiative of the YMCA France and the World YMCA;  The Change Agents programme, a global leadership development initiative of the YMCA involving participants from over 60 countries. 

The objectives of "Change Agents for Europe" are:

1. To equip youth workers with leadership skills and youth work techniques for social intervention in local communities. 

2. To increase knowledge, active citizenship and engagement on pressuring issues (such as employment, health, Human Rights and environment) affecting young people at community, national, European and global levels.

3.To prepare young people for structured dialogue and leadership/action on social relevant issues for young people.

4. To equip youth workers with networks/relationships across cultural and religious boundaries as part of a youth empowerment process in increasing multicultural societies.

5. To strengthen a European network of youth workers who can share best practices and experiences.
Youth in Action for the climat

"Youth in Action for the Climate"

2015 is a key year: the Conference of the Parties of the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change (COP 21) aims to reach a new international climate agreement applicable to all countries.
It will be held in Paris from the 30th November to the 11th December 2015.
This is a unique opportunity for young people in Europe to be present and to speak up and fight against climate change.

In this context, we will bring together young leaders from 15 European countries to express themselves, exchange and debate.
objectives:
1 - Training young people to enter into dialogue and structured action and to identify the various project possibilities open to them to engage effectively in their country.
2- Developing Active Citizenship (Youth Empowerment) in sustainable development:
- Educate young people about issues related to sustainable development (climate, biodiversity, raw materials savings, waste management, etc ...), and allow them to acquire the knowledge and skills
3- Create real impact at the COP21 in Paris and speak through the RGE (Resource Group on the Environment) during international conferences / debates
4 - Provide youth opportunities to build the European and global networks.

The participants will meet other young leaders from around the world and create real impact and change.
They will work with the RGE Group from World YMCA to bring their thoughts and feelings to the discussions at the COP 21.
This project is lead by the youth for the youth, to bring action and to share awareness.

The YMCA Leadership Academy is a seminar organised by YMCA France for NGOs across Europe to mainstream a rights based approach and democratic leadership and governance into our organisations. To do so, we aim to address young board members (under 30s), young staff and youth workers, from around 23 countries in Europe. We aim at increasing awareness among our participants about vulnerability, to increase knowledge about needs based strategic planning and project management of an NGO and to empower them to take an active role in through social mini projects. We also aim at turning the role of our NGOs towards more socially relevant activities, more inclusive of vulnerable groups and attentive to their needs and the needs of their communities. We also hope that thy will take a more active role in advocating for social justice at a local, national and European level.

The Bridging, Bonding and Linking Capitals project is borne out of a desire to create travel and learning opportunities for young people who have previously encountered obstacles and barriers in these areas. The project is a trilateral youth exchange with a strong inter-cultural European ethos between YMCA Ireland, George Williams Youth association in Kosovo, and YMCA England. Two key areas of learning focused on throughout the project are Cultural Awareness and Youth Work Practice.

The objectives of the project are to give 20 young leaders the opportunity to:
Develop cultural awareness 
Develop their knowledge base and best practice of youth work 
Achieve a Youthpass Certificate 

Profile of Participants:
Six participants from YMCA Ireland, three from Northern Ireland and three from Republic of Ireland
Six participants from George Williams Youth (GWY) association in Kosovo, all residents in Kosovo
Six from YMCA England, all residents in England
All participants are young people aged 18-25 and have faced barriers, obstacles and disadvantages in education and training, economic status, and/or living within divided societies. 
Four project managers will oversee the implementation and evaluation of the project. One from YMCA Ireland, one from YMCA England and two from George Williams Youth association in Kosovo. Project managers are aged 18-30 and together have an impressive range of experience in international youth work and management of youth organisations.

Three main activities make up the framework of the project
Activity One - Six day Youth exchange in London, England. The theme of this activity is 'Past'. Participants will visit the place where the organisation they are part of, the YMCA, was birthed in 1844 by George Williams. They will learn about the groundbreaking work of the YMCA from it's humble beginnings as well as looking into the development of youth work practice over the years. Alongside this participants will learn and share some of the history of the countries represented as well as reflecting on their own past and key moments in their lives so far.

Activity Two - Six day Youth Exchange in Pristina, Kosovo. The theme of this activity is 'Present'. Participants will learn and share about the present realities facing young people in their countries and some of the cultural traditions that continue today. Alongside this, participants will engage in discussion and debates about current youth work values and principles, issues facing young people in Europe today, and the kind of work YMCA Europe is engaged in as a response to the issues and challenges faced by young people. 

Activity Three - Six day Youth Exchange in Newcastle, Northern Ireland. The theme of this activity is 'Future'. Participants will share their hopes and dreams for their own futures as well as the kind of future they want for their country. Learning will occur around the role of youth work in driving positive social change.

Project activities will be facilitated by both project managers and participants to ensure participant directed learning can take place and young people can develop communication and facilitation skills. Non-formal learning methods will be employed at every stage of the project with an emphasis on experiential learning including cultural excursions and visiting youth work projects in each country; informal conversational times to foster the development of positive relationships; group work and group discussions giving voice to participants and encouraging them to direct the course of learning; scenario based activities; personal reflection activities allowing space for reflection on learning; group presentations; and outdoor activities with an emphasis on team building and having fun.

Envisaged results and impact
The project will result in participants being more competent and confident youth work practitioners with enhanced cultural awareness and a desire to promote values of acceptance and understanding. Participants will have developed personal and interpersonal skills making them better equipped to access further and employment opportunities. The skills and attitudes developed by participants transferable to all areas of personal, social and professional life include; increased confidence and self-awareness; enhanced communication skills; renewed sense of achievement, thorough understanding of the principle 'learning to learn' and taking control of own learning; aspiration to be active citizens and work for positive social change. The impact at local level will be an improved quality of youth work being delivered with an ethos of acceptance and understanding promoted by more competent youth work volunteers supporting paid staff.

The potential long term impacts include participants accessing leadership roles on local and national YMCA boards and all partner organisations establishing a structure to support ongoing youth exchanges to maximize mutual learning of youth.

Understanding chronic pain and improving its treatment

We will establish an international team of leading researchers and clinicians (EuroPain) to undertake multidisciplinary translational research which will: 1) increase the understanding of chronic pain mechanisms; 2)facilitate the development of novel analgesic drugs; and 3) improve the treatment of chronic pain patients.
Nineteen researchers drawn from the London Pain Consortium, the Danish Pain Research Centre, the German Pain Network and a Spanish research-intensive SME centre will form a ‘meta’ consortium with complementary expertise. The LPC is mainly laboratory based with a spectrum of skills from molecular biology and bioinformatics through integrated research in animal models to human physiological research, including imaging.The German and Danish groups have large databases on neuropathic and postsurgical pain, respectively, while the Spanish centre offers expertise in human microneurography. We will undertake a series of six interlinked and mutually supportive programs of experimental research, underpinned and supported by a coordinated training and bioinformatics facility. These programs will form a series of workpackages each delivered through collaboration of network laboratories to bring together multiple techniques and considerable expertise to each area. In addition, there will be considerable synergies between the programs. The programs, which fully address the Call, will focus on: Neurobiological mechanisms of chronic pain; Improving animal models of pain; Translational pain models in humans; Mechanisms and assessment of pain in patients; Risk factors for chronic pain.
International Laboratory of Advanced Education Technologies

We are witnessing a time where teachers are stepping out of their comfort zones and enriching their professional curriculum in favour of development, however not all communities have access to the same opportunities. European Islands share one specific trait that restrains their access to these opportunities. For their isolation and lack of human capital in general, islands are faced with lower socio-economic conditions and an underdeveloped educational system, experiencing a greater student disengagement and school dropout. Measures to improve European islands development include the promotion of new ICT technologies in education and the shift of human aspirations toward quality.

IDiverSE is an innovative project that builds up on a previous Erasmus+ project (PLATON) where members of this team also collaborate together. It uses previously created and validated as well as new innovative methods for Inquiry Based Science Learning activities.

The pilot stage of this project will include interdisciplinary collaborative Inquiry and a new methodology for the investigation of local culture. Components of ethnoscience will be applied throughout the whole project to enable students to find connections between the ancestral knowledge embedded in their cultural heritage and the classroom curricular contents thus participating in a more meaningful and valuable learning experience.

Interdisciplinary and collaborative inquiry, local culture, ethnoscience and personal geography will be integrated to create a Science Trail where students will explore their natural environment starting from the Water, continuing to the Land and ending with the Skies. Altogether the results will provide students with a holistic view of the factors that influence their lives, as their culture, their environment and their geographical conditions. Working in cooperation with schools from different islands in Europe and worldwide, through an online platform, students will also realise that each island has a different network of influences creating a diversity that brings value and uniqueness to each student’s homeland. 

IDiverSE also stands for “I Diverse” and as such it aims to include an even deeper view of Diversity, integrating each student’s internal world as unique and precious, promoting awareness for civic and ethical issues for the respect of difference. In the end the Science Trails will become available to each island’s community and students will share their findings as well as raise their community’s awareness for the Diversity concepts learnt. The whole process will be transparent and inclusive, raising their community’s understanding of the importance of development and innovation in education. The project team will then produce a Roadmap handbook that will include the IDiverSE methodology, tools and Science Trail mapping as well as the lessons learnt during the pilot implementation phase, making it freely available to other European countries.
IDiverSE is in line with the key competences for the 21st century skills for students and teachers. By promoting real scientific research and Inquiry Based activities, it challenges students to become more independent and proactive, developing their critical thinking and the capacity to find problem solving solutions. For the international cooperation component it promotes the development of social and communication skills, as well as tolerance and global citizenship.

The project foresees the involvement of at least 20 Portuguese schools, 10 Spanish schools and 10 Greek schools, divided across Madeira, Azores, Canary, Balearic islands, and distributed over several other Greek islands as part of the Rural Wings network. The project is estimated to directly reach at least 120 teachers and 1000 students living on the islands.

Teachers involve in the project will face a shift in their teaching practice, making it more student-centred and with a greater sense of interdisciplinarity and contextualization. They will be motivated to work in cooperation and to create a better and more meaningful relationship with their colleagues and students at a local and international level. By the end, teachers will be left with the project’s know-how and an enriched professional curriculum. Students, being the main target of this project will benefit from a better environment at school where cooperation is supported and motivated and with an increased feeling of involvement in the classroom. Students will discover new skills and strengths and at the same time learn to respect their own weaknesses. They will finish the project with a greater sense of self-efficacy and pride while at the same time having their work shared and recognised in and outside of their home islands. The creation of a network through ICT will be left as a bridge that stands in place of the physical connections that islands lack increasing the students’ and teachers’ international connections and opening their multicultural horizons.
